newsitem.title: INDIA: INDIAN HEADLINE STOCKS - factors to watch - Nov 5.
newsitem.headline: INDIAN HEADLINE STOCKS - factors to watch - Nov 5.

text.p: Following are some of the main factors affecting Indian stock markets on Tuesday morning:

** India's Congress party at a crucial meeting on Monday warned Prime Minister H D Deve Gowda against ignoring its interests, but said it had no immediate plans to pull down the 13-party coalition government

Deve Gowda formed his coalition in June with decisive support from the Congress after inconclusive general elections in April and May gave his group just 115 seats in the 545-member lower house of parliament
** Foreign stockbroking firms are set to enter the Indian markets in a big way with at least 10 new outfits working out plans for setting up independent brokerages, the Financial Express reports
The names include NatWest Markets, Klienwort Benson, Union Bank of Switzerland, Barclays de Zoete Wedd and CS First Boston, the paper says

** The Industrial Entrepreneurs' Memoranda received during April-September this year, projects investments worth 612.83 billion rupees - a sharp fall of 38.55 percent compared to the corresponding period last year, the Business Standard reports
** South Korean giant Samsung plans to invest over $1 billion in India to take up its total investment in the country to $2 billion by 2000 AD, according to the Financial Express
The group has identified petrochemicals and automobiles as the new thrust areas for investments in future

** A Reuters daily tracking poll of the U.S. elections, due on Tuesday, showed a late surge for Republican Bob Dole was now fading and President Bill Clinton had moved back out to a 7.3 percentage point lead -- enough for a comfortable win although perhaps not the popular-vote majority he covets
** The Indian rupee INR= opened unchanged at 35.69/70 per dollar on Tuesday. Dollar demand seen continuing, with a state-run bank bidding in early trade, dealers said
** A weak undertone put pressure on Indian share prices on Monday, with major players hesitant to build positions in the market.
The 30-share Bombay Stock Exchange index fell 55.85 points or 1.77 percent to end at 3,092.72
The 50-stock National Stock Exchange lost 16.55 points or 1.82 percent to 890.13
** Auto-component maker Sundram Fastners reported a 28 percent rise in its first-half 1996/97 (April-March) net profit to 193.0 million rupees from 150.4 million in the year-ago period
** Reliance Capital announced a 12 percent increase in its six-month net profit to 597.0 million rupees for the year ending September 30, 1996
